node.text: Fancy eating brains for dessert this Halloween? Let me show you how ;)  A delicious chocolate and vanilla cake, decorated as a fresh, moist brain. I recommend dark chocolate ganache for the inside and the outside frosting (1 part cream to 2 parts dark chocolate. I recommend 800 grams dark choc and 400 grams heavy cream). I used a 7 inch half sphere cake mould and a 7 inch square cake. Enjoy!

node.title: Try Not to Puke- How to Make Brain Cake for Halloween

node.text:
Another fresh cream upon popular demand! Here we are going all out ;) I still recommend only using fresh cream for these shorter, softer style cakes. To help make the cream cream a little stiffer and stable, I added 4 tablespoons of icing sugar to 600ml of heavy cream. Icing mixture would work wonderfully here too. The piping tips used were the 104 tip for the curtains and the 32 tip for all the rest of the decor. I hope you enjoy this one :D

node.text:
Our first Halloween cake for 2021! Let’s hit it off with the classic, gravestone silhouette design. I used all buttercream elements here, but you can also create this using a fondant cut out for the moon. This will save you from having to create a round stencil, although if you want to take your decorating to the next level, I recommend you give it a go, even to just get some practice in with stencilling! You can use a #8 or #10 round piping tip for the main body of the tree and the thicker trunks, and then a #3 piping tip for the skinnier branches. Alternatively, you can cut a 5mm hole at the end of you piping tip so more buttercream comes through for the larger, thicker trunks. For the smaller trunks, you can simply use a 2nd piping bag with a 2mm hole cut at the end instead. Enjoy!

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch. Enjoy!

node.title: How to Make a Silhouette Halloween Cake

node.text:
Apologies for being quiet these last few days! I have been busy designing a few new things for the website catalogue, including this fresh new scraper and comb in one, and finally, our range of Custom cookie presses! I have tagged the products in the video in case you would like to check these babies out. Today, I walk you through the striped effect. For best results, I find that soft buttercream / non chilled cakes leave the smoothest finish. The thinner the colour layer is on top, the less work it is for you and the quicker you can achieve those smooth, cute stripes :) 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch. Enjoy!

node.text:
Back to basics! Today we are making a tone on tone drip cake (one of my favourite basic designs) decorated with gold foliage and flowers. Gold foliage is something you can do yourself at home with either real leaves or fondant leaves. All you need is a large soft brush (blush brushes work well here) and some edible gold luster dust. Pounce the dust onto the foliage to colour it in. And voila! You have an antique looking decoration piece to add to your cake. The darker the leaves, the better the effect :)

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Going for a nice and tall one this week! Edible cake lace is the hero of this particular creation, and it is sooo easy to make. You will need to buy cake lace mixture and a silicone mat with a lace pattern of some sort. I buy both of these items from a cake decorating specialty store (my go to here in Victoria Aus is My Dream Cake, Melbourne Cake Supplies, or Miss Biscuit to name a few). 

Super tall cakes are so much fun to look at, although they can become lopsided pretty easily. For best results, I recommend keeping your cakes thick, working with cake diameters 6 inches and above (I worked with a 4 inch in this cake decorating video, and she was a little tricky haha!), use two dowels to stabilise it OR treat it as a two tier cake by adding dowels and a cake board half way through. Use either buttercream or dark chocolate ganache as a filling and outer frosting and avoid soft cream fillings. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Make your floral decorations count! Sometimes the most elegant looking cake has nothing to do with the cake at all ;) Take this simple celebration cake- the focal here is the height, fullness and colour of your bouquet. To help them pop, I would suggest choosing a frosting colour that compliments the floral colours. Build more height by applying extra cake layers or frosting as a platform and way to attach the flowers to the cakes. Go for the large florals- something with lots of body and presence / with lots of petals. You can make the stems food safe in a few ways as well. I recommend trapping the stems in plastic food wrap and feeding this through a plastic straw. You can also remove the stems completely though, and feed a wire through the base of the flower to act as the stem (covering it with food wrap and straw as well). I hope you enjoyed this little demo and tips :D

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Stepping outside of the comfort zone with this one! I have seen this cake trend over the years, but had never given it a try until now :) For the flowers, I used the floral Ball Tip Russian Piping Tip. You can find these pretty easily on e-bay / at your cake decorating specialty stores. I wanted my cakes to be a little taller than usual, so I wen’t for a medium wide cake (7 inch cakes) but anything bigger would have been even more stable again. If you want to Make a smaller version, I would suggest not making your cake as tall. This will help to keep it standing tall, without becoming lopsided. The Rosettes were created with the 1M piping tip :) probably one of my favourite tips for easy buttercream flowers. I hope you enjoy this one!

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
In this cake decorating tutorial, we will be mixing a buttercream finished cake with fondant ruffle decorations. You can however decorate the WHOLE cake using buttercream :) You would simply fill a piping bag with buttercream of each colour, fitted with a #104 piping tip. Then, pipe rings of of the buttercream around the cake, starting from top to bottom. I do prefer the look of the fondant however, as it’s much more delicate and refined, compared to buttercream. But if you are in a rush, and would prefer to cut out 30 mins from the decorating process, then buttercream piping would be the way to go.

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

You can freeze your any left over buttercream for future use for up to 2 months. Enjoy!

node.text:
A little trend I had been ITCHING to create! Here we have a twinning, buttercream decorated rainbow cake :) Easier than she looks! Although heavily time consuming, this cake is definitely worth the WOW that will come from the birthday girl or boy. Play around with the colours of the frosting as well. I used two pink cakes to have them matching, but you could also do a blue and a pink cake for example. I hope this tutorial comes in handy! I look forward to seeing what you guys create :D 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

For the white chocolate ganache, I recommend:
210 grams white chocolate
70 grams heavy cream 

Mix together until all the chocolate has been coated by the cream. Zap in the microwave for 20 seconds, stir to combine, and then zap for an additional 15 to 20 seconds and stir until the chocolate is completely melted.

node.text:
A fun way to dress up your edible blank canvas- enter chocolate spheres! I used white chocolate, vegetable oil and gel food colour to create my spheres, along with two silicone hand sphere moulds. They actually don’t take too long to make. I personally preferred using the tea spoon / spoon to fill, but you can also use a brush as well if that tickles your fancy. It trips me out how messy these actually look before yo pop them out of the mould.. I hope it inspires confidence that you don’t need to be careful with these, and no matter how ugly they look at the start, they will work out just fine in the end haha! I definitely wouldn’t skip the double layering of chocolate though. This makes all the difference in stability and the overall look of the spheres. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

I am often asked how much vegetable oil to add to your white chocolate. I recommend:
1 cup of white chocolate 
1 tablespoon of vegetable oil
2 drop of gel food colour. 
If the chocolate looks as though it is going to harden after mixing the gel food colour, then add in an extra teaspoon of oil. This usually does the trick :)

node.title: How to Make Chocolate Spheres- Cake Tutorial

node.text:
This cake decorating tutorial features gum paste, but you can also use fondant for this project if you aren’t able to find gum paste :) 
I recently bought this lace stencil for a future wedding cake I’ll be making for a good friend of mine, and I couldn’t wait to try it out! I didn’t want to use up what little I had of the edible lace mixture, so I settled for embossed gum paste instead ;) 
Granted, you don’t have to go out and buy a silicone lace mould for this. There are plastic lace table runners that you can find at your local Manchester store or bargain store which are raised enough to easily impress onto fondant. Doilies will do the same thing, and you would simply follow the same steps as I have here. I hope this little technique comes in handy!

Also, I didn’t have a sponge brush on hand, but if you can find one, it would work even better at accurately painting the raised area, and just the raised area, with minimal bleeding of colour where you don’t want it to go. If you only have a paint brush though, try for something that can be pressed flat, so it swipes against the surface, without the bristles unbundling and possibly getting into the indented sections. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)
 Enjoy!

node.text: Fancy eating brains for dessert this Halloween? Let me show you how ;)  A delicious chocolate and vanilla cake, decorated as a fresh, moist brain. I recommend dark chocolate ganache for the inside and the outside frosting (1 part cream to 2 parts dark chocolate. I recommend 800 grams dark choc and 400 grams heavy cream). I used a 7 inch half sphere cake mould and a 7 inch square cake. Enjoy!

node.text:
Another fresh cream upon popular demand! Here we are going all out ;) I still recommend only using fresh cream for these shorter, softer style cakes. To help make the cream cream a little stiffer and stable, I added 4 tablespoons of icing sugar to 600ml of heavy cream. Icing mixture would work wonderfully here too. The piping tips used were the 104 tip for the curtains and the 32 tip for all the rest of the decor. I hope you enjoy this one :D

node.text:
Our first Halloween cake for 2021! Let’s hit it off with the classic, gravestone silhouette design. I used all buttercream elements here, but you can also create this using a fondant cut out for the moon. This will save you from having to create a round stencil, although if you want to take your decorating to the next level, I recommend you give it a go, even to just get some practice in with stencilling! You can use a #8 or #10 round piping tip for the main body of the tree and the thicker trunks, and then a #3 piping tip for the skinnier branches. Alternatively, you can cut a 5mm hole at the end of you piping tip so more buttercream comes through for the larger, thicker trunks. For the smaller trunks, you can simply use a 2nd piping bag with a 2mm hole cut at the end instead. Enjoy!

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch. Enjoy!

node.text:
Apologies for being quiet these last few days! I have been busy designing a few new things for the website catalogue, including this fresh new scraper and comb in one, and finally, our range of Custom cookie presses! I have tagged the products in the video in case you would like to check these babies out. Today, I walk you through the striped effect. For best results, I find that soft buttercream / non chilled cakes leave the smoothest finish. The thinner the colour layer is on top, the less work it is for you and the quicker you can achieve those smooth, cute stripes :) 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch. Enjoy!

node.text:
Back to basics! Today we are making a tone on tone drip cake (one of my favourite basic designs) decorated with gold foliage and flowers. Gold foliage is something you can do yourself at home with either real leaves or fondant leaves. All you need is a large soft brush (blush brushes work well here) and some edible gold luster dust. Pounce the dust onto the foliage to colour it in. And voila! You have an antique looking decoration piece to add to your cake. The darker the leaves, the better the effect :)

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Going for a nice and tall one this week! Edible cake lace is the hero of this particular creation, and it is sooo easy to make. You will need to buy cake lace mixture and a silicone mat with a lace pattern of some sort. I buy both of these items from a cake decorating specialty store (my go to here in Victoria Aus is My Dream Cake, Melbourne Cake Supplies, or Miss Biscuit to name a few). 

Super tall cakes are so much fun to look at, although they can become lopsided pretty easily. For best results, I recommend keeping your cakes thick, working with cake diameters 6 inches and above (I worked with a 4 inch in this cake decorating video, and she was a little tricky haha!), use two dowels to stabilise it OR treat it as a two tier cake by adding dowels and a cake board half way through. Use either buttercream or dark chocolate ganache as a filling and outer frosting and avoid soft cream fillings. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Make your floral decorations count! Sometimes the most elegant looking cake has nothing to do with the cake at all ;) Take this simple celebration cake- the focal here is the height, fullness and colour of your bouquet. To help them pop, I would suggest choosing a frosting colour that compliments the floral colours. Build more height by applying extra cake layers or frosting as a platform and way to attach the flowers to the cakes. Go for the large florals- something with lots of body and presence / with lots of petals. You can make the stems food safe in a few ways as well. I recommend trapping the stems in plastic food wrap and feeding this through a plastic straw. You can also remove the stems completely though, and feed a wire through the base of the flower to act as the stem (covering it with food wrap and straw as well). I hope you enjoyed this little demo and tips :D

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
Stepping outside of the comfort zone with this one! I have seen this cake trend over the years, but had never given it a try until now :) For the flowers, I used the floral Ball Tip Russian Piping Tip. You can find these pretty easily on e-bay / at your cake decorating specialty stores. I wanted my cakes to be a little taller than usual, so I wen’t for a medium wide cake (7 inch cakes) but anything bigger would have been even more stable again. If you want to Make a smaller version, I would suggest not making your cake as tall. This will help to keep it standing tall, without becoming lopsided. The Rosettes were created with the 1M piping tip :) probably one of my favourite tips for easy buttercream flowers. I hope you enjoy this one!

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

node.text:
In this cake decorating tutorial, we will be mixing a buttercream finished cake with fondant ruffle decorations. You can however decorate the WHOLE cake using buttercream :) You would simply fill a piping bag with buttercream of each colour, fitted with a #104 piping tip. Then, pipe rings of of the buttercream around the cake, starting from top to bottom. I do prefer the look of the fondant however, as it’s much more delicate and refined, compared to buttercream. But if you are in a rush, and would prefer to cut out 30 mins from the decorating process, then buttercream piping would be the way to go.

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

You can freeze your any left over buttercream for future use for up to 2 months. Enjoy!

node.text:
A little trend I had been ITCHING to create! Here we have a twinning, buttercream decorated rainbow cake :) Easier than she looks! Although heavily time consuming, this cake is definitely worth the WOW that will come from the birthday girl or boy. Play around with the colours of the frosting as well. I used two pink cakes to have them matching, but you could also do a blue and a pink cake for example. I hope this tutorial comes in handy! I look forward to seeing what you guys create :D 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

For the white chocolate ganache, I recommend:
210 grams white chocolate
70 grams heavy cream 

Mix together until all the chocolate has been coated by the cream. Zap in the microwave for 20 seconds, stir to combine, and then zap for an additional 15 to 20 seconds and stir until the chocolate is completely melted.

node.text:
A fun way to dress up your edible blank canvas- enter chocolate spheres! I used white chocolate, vegetable oil and gel food colour to create my spheres, along with two silicone hand sphere moulds. They actually don’t take too long to make. I personally preferred using the tea spoon / spoon to fill, but you can also use a brush as well if that tickles your fancy. It trips me out how messy these actually look before yo pop them out of the mould.. I hope it inspires confidence that you don’t need to be careful with these, and no matter how ugly they look at the start, they will work out just fine in the end haha! I definitely wouldn’t skip the double layering of chocolate though. This makes all the difference in stability and the overall look of the spheres. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk

1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)

I am often asked how much vegetable oil to add to your white chocolate. I recommend:
1 cup of white chocolate 
1 tablespoon of vegetable oil
2 drop of gel food colour. 
If the chocolate looks as though it is going to harden after mixing the gel food colour, then add in an extra teaspoon of oil. This usually does the trick :)

node.text:
This cake decorating tutorial features gum paste, but you can also use fondant for this project if you aren’t able to find gum paste :) 
I recently bought this lace stencil for a future wedding cake I’ll be making for a good friend of mine, and I couldn’t wait to try it out! I didn’t want to use up what little I had of the edible lace mixture, so I settled for embossed gum paste instead ;) 
Granted, you don’t have to go out and buy a silicone lace mould for this. There are plastic lace table runners that you can find at your local Manchester store or bargain store which are raised enough to easily impress onto fondant. Doilies will do the same thing, and you would simply follow the same steps as I have here. I hope this little technique comes in handy!

Also, I didn’t have a sponge brush on hand, but if you can find one, it would work even better at accurately painting the raised area, and just the raised area, with minimal bleeding of colour where you don’t want it to go. If you only have a paint brush though, try for something that can be pressed flat, so it swipes against the surface, without the bristles unbundling and possibly getting into the indented sections. 

For the buttercream, I recommend:
500 grams unsalted butter
500 grams vegetable shortening (replace with the same amount of unsalted butter if you don't want to use this)
2kg icing sugar
2 tsp vanilla
3 to 5 tablespoons milk
 
1. beat the unsalted butter and vege shortening together on medium speed for 5 mins using a paddle attachment. 
2. add in icing sugar in 3 batches, mixing for 3 minutes after each addition on medium speed. 3. add in vanilla and your milk and mix for another 4 mins. I recommend adding the milk slowly and assessing the consistency of your buttercream. You may not need all of it, or you may need extra depending on your batch :)
 Enjoy!
